title: Glamorous revellers refuse to let the rain dampen their parade as they party at Listen Out festival
text:
Young revellers have paraded their latest risque outfits at the Listen Out festival and have been met with a heavy presence of police and security staff.

Listen Out is an over 18s Australian dance and music event, featuring multiple hip hop and electronic artists across four inner city venues across the country.

More than 30,000 festival goers flocked to celebrate at Centennial Park, in the eastern suburbs of Sydney.

Some patrons arrived wearing very risqué outfits ready to have a fun-filled day listening to the long list of artists who were due to play.

Australian record producer, Flume, made a special appearance and performed for the first time in the country since the Falls Festival last year.

It comes as the 27-year-old released his mixtape Hi This Is Flume, earlier this year.

There was a marked police presence for the start of the festival season after five young revellers died at events last spring and summer due to suspected drug overdoses.

There were spot searches of festival goers and several were seen being led away by police.

There were also some revellers who immediately required assistance from paramedics.

Australian record producer, Flume, made a special appearance and performed for the first time in the country since the Falls Festival last year

Listen Out is the first festival that was approved under the NSW Governments strict regulations following the five deaths last summer

Listen Out is the first festival that was approved under the NSW Governments strict regulations following the five deaths.

The government is looking to crackdown on those who bring illicit drugs to these festivities which have seen young lives lost.

NSW Premier Gladys Berejiklian has rejected pill testing previously stating that there's 'not enough evidence' that it works.

'They haven't shown there's any evidence yet,' the Premier explained.

'My position on pill testing remains firm. I don't think it works, I don't think the evidence is there and I don't support it.'

Despite the grey skies, revellers threw on their best outfits as they prepared for a day of fun

Pill testing would allow revellers to know how strong a pill was before it was taken and cautioned about the risk.

Critics said such testing gave tacit approval to illegal activity and a misreading of tablet strength could lead people into a false sense of security.
